general.name: Helium
general.appearance: colorless gas, exhibiting a red-orange glow when placed in a high-voltage electric field

history.first-isolation: William Ramsay, Per Teodor Cleve, Abraham Langlet (1895)

history.discovered-by: Joseph Louis Gay-Lussac and Louis Jacques Thénard

physical-properties.molar-heat-capacity:
graphite: 8.517 J mol−1 K−1
diamond: 6.155 J mol−1 K−1

atomic-properties.covalent-radius:
sp3: 77 pm
sp2: 73 pm
sp: 69 pm

miscellaneous.thermal-conductivity:
graphite: 119–165 W m−1 K−1
diamond: 900–2300 W m−1 K−1

general.name: Fluorine
general.appearance:
gas: very pale yellow
liquid: bright yellow
solid: alpha allotrope is opaque, beta allotrope is transparent

physical-properties.molar-heat-capacity:
Cp: 31 J mol−1 K−1 (at 21.1 °C)
Cv: 23 J mol−1 K−1 (at 21.1 °C)

general.name: Neon
general.appearance: colorless gas exhibiting an orange-red glow when placed in a high voltage electric field

general.name: Phosphorous
general.appearance: colourless, waxy white, yellow, scarlet, red, violet, black

miscellaneous.thermal-conductivity:
white: 0.236 W m−1 K−1
black: 12.1 W m−1 K−1

general.name: Argon
general.appearance: colorless gas exhibiting a lilac/violet glow when placed in a high voltage electric field

atomic-properties.oxidation-states: 6, 5, 4, 3, 2, 1, −1, −2 ​(depending on the oxidation state, an acidic, basic, or amphoteric oxide)

atomic-properties.covalent-radius:
Low spin: 139 ± 5 pm
High spin: 161 ± 8 pm
atomic-properties.oxidation-states: 7, 6, 5, 4, 3, 2, 1, −1, −2, −3 ​acidic, basic or amphoteric; depending on the oxidation state

general.name: Iron
general.appearance: lustrous metallic with a grayish tinge

atomic-properties.covalent-radius:
Low spin: 132 ± 3 pm
High spin: 152 ± 6 pm

miscellaneous.crystal-structure:
body-centered cubic (bcc), a=286.65 pm
face-centered cubic (fcc) between 1185–1667 K

atomic-properties.covalent-radius:
Low spin: 126 ± 3 pm
High spin: 150 ± 7 pm

general.name: Nickel
general.appearance: lustrous, metallic, and silver with a gold tinge

history.discovery-and-first-isolation: Jöns Jakob Berzelius and Johann Gottlieb Gahn (1817)
Antoine Jérôme Balard and Leopold Gmelin (1825)

general.name: Krypton
general.appearance: colorless gas, exhibiting a whitish glow in a high electric field

history.discovery-and-first-isolation: Karl Samuel Leberecht Hermann and Friedrich Stromeyer (1817)

history.discovered-by: Ferdinand Reich and Hieronymous Theodor Richter

general.name: Iodine
general.appearance: lustrous metallic gray, violet as a gas

general.name: Xenon
general.appearance: colorless gas, exhibiting a blue glow when placed in a high voltage electric field

atomic-properties.oxidation-states: 0, +1, +2, +4, +6, +8 ​(rarely more than 0; a weakly acidic oxide)

miscellaneous.speed-of-sound:
gas: 169 m s−1
liquid: 1090 m s−1

history.discovered-by: Martin Heinrich Klaproth, Jöns Jakob Berzelius, Wilhelm Hisinger

miscellaneous.crystal-structure:
β-Ce: double hexagonal close-packed (dhcp)
γ-Ce: ​face-centered cubic (fcc)

history.discovered-by: Chien Shiung Wu, Emilio Segrè, Hans Bethe
history.first-isolation: Charles D. Coryell, Jacob A. Marinsky, Lawrence E. Glendenin, Harold G. Richter (1945)

general.name: Europium
general.appearance: silvery white, but rarely seen without oxide discoloration

history.discovered-by: Georges Urbain and Carl Auer von Welsbach

history.discovery-and-first-isolation: Dirk Coster and George de Hevesy (1922)

history.first-isolation: Juan José Elhuyar and Fausto Elhuyar (1783)

history.named-by: Walter Noddack, Ida Noddack, Otto Berg (1922)

history.discovered-by: Dale R. Corson, Kenneth Ross MacKenzie, Emilio Segrè

general.name: Radon
general.appearance: colorless gas, occasionally glows green or red in discharge tubes

atomic-properties.oxidation-states: 2 ​(expected to have a strongly basic oxide)

general.name: Actinium
general.appearance: silvery-white, glowing with an eerie blue light; sometimes with a golden cast

general.name: Uranium
general.appearance: silvery gray metallic; corrodes to a spalling black oxide coat in air

history.discovered-by: Edwin McMillan and Philip H. Abelson

general.name: Plutonium
general.appearance: silvery white, tarnishing to dark gray in air

history.discovery: Glenn T. Seaborg, Arthur Wahl, Joseph W. Kennedy, Edwin McMillan (1940 – 1941)
Glenn T. Seaborg, Ralph A. James, Leon O. Morgan, Albert Ghiorso (1944)

history.discovered-by: Glenn T. Seaborg, Ralph A. James, Albert Ghiorso

history.discovery: Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory and Joint Institute for Nuclear Research (1961–1971)
Joint Institute for Nuclear Research and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (2003)
Joint Institute for Nuclear Research and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (1999)
Joint Institute for Nuclear Research and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (2003)
Joint Institute for Nuclear Research and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (2000)
Joint Institute for Nuclear Research and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (2010)
Joint Institute for Nuclear Research and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (2002)
